channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: China’s Role in Iran-Saudi Deal Shows Xi’s Challenge to U.S.-led Order
item.description: Brokering a rapprochement between the Middle Eastern rivals underscores the Chinese leader’s ambition of offering an alternative to a U.S.-led world order.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:description: Wang Yi, center, China’s top foreign policy official, with Ali Shamkhani, right, the secretary of Iran’s security council, and Musaad al-Aiban, Saudi Arabia’s minister of state, in Beijing on Friday.

item.title: In World Cup Run-Up, Qatar Pressed U.N. Agency Not to Investigate Abuses
item.description: Lobbying at the International Labor Organization dovetailed with an influence campaign that set off a corruption scandal at the European Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca R. Ruiz and Sarah Hurtes
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A worker during the World Cup in November in Doha, Qatar. The country, which has spent years tamping down criticism of its human rights record, lobbied influential labor groups in the build-up to the tournament.

item.title: In Fields Sown With Bombs, Ukraine’s Farmers Risk Deadly Harvest
item.description: Some who till the breadbaskets of Ukraine have already lost three seasons of planting to war. With mines and cluster bombs widely scattered, normal harvests seem far in the future.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Stanislav Kozliuk and Ivor Prickett
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oleksandr Hordienko, right, and Serhii Mikhailechko checked for mines near the site where a family were killed when they drove over a Russian anti-tank mine in the Beryslav region of Ukraine, in February.

item.title: Trial in ‘Argentina, 1985’ Began Quest for Justice That Continues Today
item.description: “Argentina, 1985” has resurrected the country’s military rule, which ended 40 years ago. The quest persists to hold those accused of crimes against humanity accountable.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Alcoba
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Anita Pouchard Serra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pictures of missing people at the Naval Mechanics School, also known as the ESMA, a former clandestine center for detention, torture and killings, in Buenos Aires.

item.title: BBC in Turmoil as Revolt Over Gary Lineker’s ‘Match of the Day’ Suspension Spreads
item.description: One of England’s best-known sports personalities, he was taken off the air after criticizing a British government immigration proposal on social media. His ouster set off a staff boycott.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Das, Michael Levenson and Tariq Panja
item.media:description: Mr. Lineker has frequently engaged in debates on social media, which has sometimes led to criticism that he is violating the BBC’s guidelines on impartiality.

item.title: An Activist’s Flight Reveals Widening Repression in Algeria
item.description: Four years after a popular uprising fueled hopes for change and real democracy, the country’s government is using vaguely defined statutes to round up hundreds.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amira Bouraoui’s case is part of what academics and human rights groups have described as an intensifying crackdown by the Algerian government on civil society.

item.title: Corruption Watchdog Moves to Clear Cyril Ramaphosa
item.description: After $580,000 was stolen from a sofa of President Cyril Ramaphosa, his head of security skirted regulations, but the president did not, according to a preliminary report by a corruption watchdog.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa speaking during the opening of the African National Congress 55th national conference in Johannesburg in December.

item.title: The Tech Worker With a 4-Hour Commute From the West Bank to Tel Aviv
item.description: Moha Alshawamreh is among the few Palestinians who work in Israel’s tech industry. His commute shows both the inequities of life in the West Bank and an exception to them.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Moha Alshawamreh in his village, Deir al-Asal al-Fauqa. It lies just east of a gray wall, hundreds of miles long, that Israel built to curb Palestinian attacks from the West Bank.

item.title: Front Line Shifts in Russia and Ukraine’s Bakhmut Battle, Analysts Say
item.description: Britain’s defense intelligence agency said that Russian forces had taken control of most of Bakhmut’s east, but advances farther west might be challenging.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers targeting Russian forces to support their infantry near Bakhmut, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: Saudi Arabia and Iran Agree to Resume Diplomatic Relations
item.description: The deal between regional rivals underlines China’s growing economic and political importance in the Middle East, and what some analysts say is waning American influence.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: A photograph released by Saudi Arabia’s press agency on Friday showed Musaad al-Aiban, a Saudi minister of state, left, and Ali Shamkhani, Iran’s secretary of the National Security Council, in Beijing.

item.title: Saudi Deal With Iran Surprises Israel and Jolts Netanyahu
item.description: Israel had long hoped to isolate Iran and seal ties with Saudi Arabia. A thaw between Riyadh and Tehran has complicated that goal — and was perceived as politically damaging to the prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel during a cabinet meeting at the prime minister’s office in Jerusalem, last month.

item.title: Criminals in Mexico Violated Their Unwritten Rule: Leave Americans Alone
item.description: While Mexicans are often caught in cartel violence, and the outside world barely notices, the criminal groups know that targeting Americans is bad for business.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers on patrol outside the Forensic Medical Service morgue building in Matamoros, Mexico, on Wednesday.

item.title: China Appoints Xi Jinping Loyalist Li Qiang as Premier
item.description: The former Communist Party leader of Shanghai and now occupying the No. 2 spot, Mr. Li is among the men who will be leading the nation for the next five years.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Mark R. Cristino
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, speaking with Li Qiang during a session of the National People’s Congress in Beijing on Friday.

item.title: Canadian Supreme Court Judge Put on Leave During Review of Altercation in Arizona
item.description: The judge denied instigating the episode, which an oversight council has been investigating for several weeks.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Justice Russell Brown in the courtroom of the Supreme Court of Canada in Ottawa in 2019.

item.title: How Mia Couto’s Words Help Weave the Story of Mozambique
item.description: Couto’s language is enriched by his country’s idioms, voices — and possibilities. “We are still in the process of creating one nation,” he said, made of “different languages, different beliefs.”
item.dc:creator: Jacob Judah
item.media:credit: Nii Obodai for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We are building myths,” said Mia Couto of the role of writers in Mozambique. “We are still in the process of creating one nation; one nation that can bring together these different languages, different beliefs. We are substitutes for the prophets.”

item.title: It’s Oscar Time
item.description: Get your popcorn. Manage your expectations. The 95th Academy Awards are tomorrow.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: A National Medical License May Ease Canada’s Doctor Shortages
item.description: The Canadian Medical Association is pushing for a single license to eliminate the barriers between provinces and territories.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Jackie Dives for The New York Times
item.media:description: Applying for a medical license in another province is costly and time-consuming.

item.title: Inside One of the World’s Biggest Green Hydrogen Projects
item.description: Hundreds of billions of dollars are being invested in a high-tech gamble to make hydrogen clean, cheap and widely available. In Australia’s Outback, that starts with 10 million new solar panels.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak and Giacomo d’Orlando
item.media:credit: Giacomo d'Orlando for The New York Times

item.title: Iran-Saudi Pact Is Brokered by China, Leaving U.S. on Sidelines
item.description: The agreement negotiated in Beijing to restore relations between Saudi Arabia and Iran signaled at least a temporary reordering of the usual alliances and rivalries, with Washington left on the sidelines.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: A photograph released by Chinese state media showing officials Wang Yi, center, China’s top foreign policy official, with Ali Shamkhani, right, the secretary of Iran’s security council, and Musaad bin Mohammed Al Aiban, Saudi Arabia’s minister of state, in Beijing, on Friday.

item.title: Biden Administration Expected to Move Ahead on a Major Oil Project in Alaska
item.description: The decision would allow an enormous $8 billion drilling project in the largest expanse of pristine wilderness in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: Activists gathered outside the White House this month to call on President Biden to halt the Willow Project in Alaska.

item.title: Macron Welcomes Sunak to Paris, Hinting at a New Chapter
item.description: The rapport between Emmanuel Macron of France and Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain hints at a mending of their countries’ relationship.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Britain’s prime minister, Rishi Sunak, left, and France’s president, Emmanuel Macron, after a French-British summit at the Élysée Palace in Paris on Friday.

item.title: Migrants Face Navigating Bureaucracy After a Hard Journey
item.description: The Biden administration’s new rules have brought down a record number of border crossings, but critics say they expose the pitfalls of policies intended to manage an immediate problem.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan and Steve Fisher
item.media:description: Customs and Border Protection agents on the bridge between Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, and El Paso last month. The agents reviewed a list of names of people who had requested appointments to seek asylum using the C.B.P. One app.

item.title: Traute Lafrenz, Last Survivor of Anti-Hitler Group, Dies at 103
item.description: As a member of the White Rose, a small anti-Nazi resistance group, she used peaceful tactics to try persuading Germans to turn against Hitler.
item.dc:creator: Alan Cowell
item.media:description: Traute Lafrenz in 1942. She helped the group known as the White Rose gain access to ink, paper and envelopes to produce political leaflets that urged Germans to turn against the Nazis.

item.title: Interpreting the Week’s Most Important Stories
item.description: The larger themes behind the protests in Israel, the U.K.’s tough new immigration plan and a fight over U.S. labor unions.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Israelis protest in Tel Aviv on Thursday against plans by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government to overhaul the judicial system.

item.title: Funeral for Dmytro Kotsiubailo, Known as ‘Da Vinci,’ Draws Crowds in Kyiv
item.description: Dmytro Kotsiubailo, better known as “Da Vinci,” was killed near Bakhmut on March 7.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers kneeling down while the coffin is taken to Kyiv’s Independence Square.

item.title: What to Know About the Iran-Saudi Deal
item.description: The regional rivals have agreed to re-establish diplomatic ties in an agreement brokered by China that could reverberate across the Middle East and beyond.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Shashank Bengali
item.media:description: A photo released by the Iranian agency NourNews on Friday showed, from left, Musaad al-Aiban, a Saudi minister; Wang Yi, China’s most senior foreign policy official; and Ali Shamkhani, head of Iran’s Supreme National Security Council, in Beijing.

item.title: Giving the Middle Finger Is a ‘God-Given’ Right, a Quebec Judge Says
item.description: In dismissing a harassment case, the judge wrote that the right to make the obscene gesture is one “that belongs to every red-blooded Canadian.”
item.dc:creator: McKenna Oxenden
item.media:description: The Palais de Justice, Montreal’s criminal courts building. “To be abundantly clear, it is not a crime to give someone the finger,” Judge Dennis Galiatsatos wrote in a ruling dismissing a criminal case.

item.title: Pregnant Russians Flock to Argentina to Gain a Shot at Citizenship
item.description: Since the Ukraine war, pregnant Russians have been flocking to the South American country where obtaining citizenship is relatively easy — if your child is born there.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Alcoba
item.media:credit: Sarah Pabst for The New York Times
item.media:description: Irina Bugaeva nursing her 4-month-old son, Duolan, who was born in Buenos Aires, while her daughter, Leia, played on the sofa in their apartment in Buenos Aires.

item.title: Prince Edward Receives a New Title on His Birthday
item.description: King Charles III named Edward, his youngest brother, the Duke of Edinburgh on his 59th birthday. The title was previously held by their father, Prince Philip.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Press Association, via Associated Press Images
item.media:description: Prince Edward, Prince Philip and Edward’s wife, Sophie, in 2016. Edward has been granted his father’s former title, the Duke of Edinburgh.

item.title: Gunman Kills 6 in Shooting at Jehovah’s Witness Hall in Germany
item.description: The attacker received a warning but was allowed to keep his weapons after the authorities received an anonymous letter about him, weeks before he killed six people at his former congregation.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze and Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: Four men and two women, one of whom was pregnant, were killed in the attack.

item.title: Why Unions Matter So Much
item.description: Is the Democratic Party again starting to pay more attention to them?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Emily Elconin for The New York Times
item.media:description: UAW workers listen to a House Labor Committee meeting in Michigan on Wednesday.

item.title: Georgia Drops ‘Foreign Agents’ Bill That Set Off Protests Over Parallels to Russia
item.description: Although the U-turn was considered a victory for civil society, activists on both sides of the issue suggested that the fight was not over.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Protesters near Georgia’s Parliament in the capital, Tbilisi, on Thursday.

item.title: Israel Judicial Overhaul: What Led to Protests of Netanyahu’s Plan
item.description: Israeli society is locked in a deep dispute over the future of its judiciary and democracy. The conflict is rooted in shifts of the last three decades.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest last month in Jerusalem against plans by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government to overhaul Israel’s judicial system. The protests have been some of the largest in the country’s history.

item.title: Biden and E.U. Leader Seek Common Ground on Trade and Ukraine
item.description: President Biden and the European Commission president met to discuss how to effectively counter Russia and a potential trade deal for electric vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Commission, met with President Biden on Friday. European allies have expressed frustration over a new U.S. law that offers tax credits to American consumers to buy electric vehicles made in North America.

item.title: Legacy of Australia’s Immigration Policies Haunts Survivors and Supporters
item.description: The country’s grueling detention programs have ensnared thousands — and appear to flout international law.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A rally for refugee rights in Sydney, Australia, in July.

item.title: The leaders of Britain and France met in Paris with Ukraine on the agenda.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain, left, with President Emmanuel Macron of France in Paris on Friday.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: The toll of Russia’s Thursday morning assault on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cars destroyed by an airstrike in Kyiv, Ukraine.

item.title: China’s Top Leader Xi Jinping Starts Third Term
item.description: The Communist Party-controlled legislature endorsed Xi Jinping for an unprecedented third term as China’s president in a ritual ballot, cementing his dominance.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: Chinese leader Xi Jinping taking his oath after he is unanimously elected as President during a session of China’s National People’s Congress (NPC) at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, on Friday.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Offers Its Price to Normalize Relations With Israel
item.description: The Saudi crown prince is seeking a civilian nuclear program and security assurances from President Biden, a steep price for an agreement long sought by Israel.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley, Vivian Nereim and Patrick Kingsley
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:description: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman and Saudi officials are seeking guarantees from the United States in exchange for normalizing relations with Israel.

item.title: Russia Blasts Ukrainian Cities, Including Biggest Use of Advanced Missiles
item.description: Of 81 missiles fired, six were hypersonic weapons, among Russia’s newest and most advanced, which are all but impossible to shoot down.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Three rockets launched against Ukraine from Russia’s Belgorod region are seen at dawn in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Mexico Kidnapping: Men Found With a Note Blaming Them for Attack on Americans
item.description: The note, which was purportedly written by a powerful drug cartel, apologized for the attack last week that left three people dead, and offered up five men it said were responsible.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers guarded a morgue where the bodies of two Americans killed last week in an attack were held, in Matamoros, Mexico, on Wednesday.

item.title: Honduras Lifts Longtime Ban on ‘Morning After’ Pills
item.description: President Xiomara Castro signed an executive order on Wednesday, lifting a 2009 ban on emergency contraceptive pills.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez and Joan Suazo
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: President Xiomara Castro of Honduras addressing the United Nations General Assembly in New York in 2022. She signed an executive order lifting a ban on emergency contraceptive pills on Wednesday.

item.title: Shooting in Hamburg, Germany, Leaves Several Dead at Jehovah’s Witness Hall
item.description: A police spokesman said there were no indications that a shooter remained at large in the attack, on a Jehovah’s Witness hall in Hamburg.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze

item.title: Here’s why experts are concerned about the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant’s safety risks.
item.description: The nuclear plant, the largest in Europe, has been forced to resort to its emergency diesel generators six times since Russia launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant seen from the city of Nikopol in October.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Australia’s U.S. Nuclear Submarine Deal
item.description: Also, Russia hits targets across Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: The crew of the USS Delaware last month. A new submarine deal adds complexities to a 2021 security pact between the Australia, Britain and the United States, known as AUKUS.

item.title: Georgia Protests Quiet Down as Government Pulls Back Russian-Style Law
item.description: But opposition leaders dismissed the move and warned that the government had not given up hope.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Protesters near the Georgian Parliament in Tbilisi on Thursday listened to a speaker during a rally against a bill aimed at curbing the influence of “foreign agents.”

item.title: Satellite images show widespread destruction after heavy fighting in Bakhmut
item.description: New satellite pictures of the eastern Ukrainian city, where a brutal battle has been raging for months, showed bridges over a strategically important river had been destroyed.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao and Marco Hernandez

item.title: Nigeria Postpones State Elections Amid Presidential Vote Controversy
item.description: The government moved elections scheduled for Saturday back by a week, saying it needed more time to reset digital voting machines at the center of fraud accusations.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Oladeinde Olawoyin
item.media:credit: Pius Utomi Ekpei/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A campaign billboard for a Lagos governor candidate on Tuesday. Nigeria’s election commission is postponing the election for 28 of the country’s 36 state governors.

item.title: Russia’s Use of Hypersonic Missiles in Ukraine Raises Questions
item.description: Moscow on Thursday fired the largest number of the air-launched weapons used in a single wave since the war began a year ago.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Russian MiG-31 jets carrying hypersonic Kinzhal missiles over Red Square during the Victory Day military parade in Moscow in 2018.

item.title: Latvia Is Sending Cars Seized From Drunken Drivers to Ukraine
item.description: The first batch of cars will start making their way on Friday, the head of a charity helping deliver them said, and will go to the military and hospitals.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: A trailer in Riga, Latvia, loaded with confiscated vehicles to send to Ukraine.

item.title: These Morning-After Pills May Prevent STI’s, Researchers Say
item.description: Taking a common antibiotic after sex greatly reduces the chances of developing syphilis, chlamydia and gonorrhea among men who have sex with men and among trans women.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
item.media:description: The antibiotic doxycycline seems most effective for preventing chlamydia and syphilis and slightly less effective for preventing gonorrhea.

item.title: Cyclone Freddy Lashes Mozambique and Madagascar
item.description: The storm, which has killed 21 people already, has hit several countries in southeastern Africa and is on track to last longer than the record of 31 days.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Destruction wrought by Cyclone Freddy in Madagascar on Feb. 22. The storm has bounced between Mozambique and Madagascar, gaining and losing intensity.

item.title: Australia to Buy U.S. Nuclear-Powered Submarines in Deal to Counter China
item.description: The arrangement also involves submarine construction by Britain and deepens a strategic partnership that the three countries have formed as China continues to build up its military.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave and Edward Wong
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: The crew of the USS Delaware last month. A new submarine deal adds complexities to a 2021 security pact between Australia, Britain and the United States, known as AUKUS.

item.title: Mass Protests Over Netanyahu Judicial Overhaul Sweep Israel
item.description: A demonstration against a proposed judicial overhaul blocked a road to the country’s main airport, near Tel Aviv, disrupting a visit by the U.S. defense secretary.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Protesters during a rally against the government’s judicial overhaul plan in Tel Aviv on Thursday.

item.title: Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Outage Amid Russian Shelling Prompts Fiery U.N. Response
item.description: It’s the sixth time the facility had to move to its emergency power supply since Russia invaded Ukraine a year ago.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant, seen from the city of Nikopol in the southern part of Ukraine’s eastern Dnipro region, in October.

item.title: The Debate Over Covid’s Origin
item.description: Both U.S. political parties are now open to the idea that Covid may have come from a lab in China.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: Witnesses during the first hearing on the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Colorful, Iconic Jeepneys May Soon Be Off the Road in the Philippines
item.description: The passenger vehicles have been ubiquitous for decades. The way the government wants to replace them with pricey new minibuses is rankling operators.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.media:description: The loud and colorful jeepneys are ubiquitous on the busy city streets of Manila, and the rest of the Philippines.

item.title: The Russian Singer Shaman Changes His Tune to Support Putin
item.description: As the Kremlin seeks to remake Russia’s institutions to comport with its militaristic worldview, cultural figures are picking a side. One singer made his choice — and is growing rich.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Georgy Birger
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yaroslav Y. Dronov, known by his stage name Shaman, performing in Rosa Khutor, Russia, last month.

item.title: African Countries Made Huge Gains in Life Expectancy. Now That Could Be Erased.
item.description: Incidence of illnesses such as diabetes and hypertension is climbing quickly in most sub-Saharan countries, but the conditions are rarely diagnosed or treated.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:credit: Malin Fezehai for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Kimani, who lives in Nairobi, was diagnosed with diabetes in 2015. He spends about 10 percent of his monthly income on medication and test strips to manage his illness.

item.title: Georgia Plans to Withdraw Foreign Agents Bill After Protests
item.description: It was not clear whether the government intended to scrap the legislation, which critics said mimicked a law that stifles dissent in Russia, or was merely delaying it to assuage protesters.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A protest near Parliament in Tbilisi, Georgia, on Thursday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Criticism in the U.S. of Israel’s judicial overhaul plan.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Protesters outside a U.S. Embassy building in Israel.

item.title: McCarthy Turns Down Zelensky’s Invitation to Visit Ukraine
item.description: In an interview with CNN, the Ukrainian leader had said the House speaker should go see firsthand what’s happening.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:description: Speaker Kevin McCarthy at the Capitol on Wednesday.
